intro: Orthocarpus faucibarbatus var. albidus, commonly known as the white-flowered orthocarpus, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbel-like inflorescences. The plant features slender, hairy stems and lanceolate leaves with a strong, spicy scent. Its flowers are small and white, often arranged in clusters, and it is typically found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. This variant is distinguished by its pale flowers and is of interest to botanists and horticulturists due to its unique morphology and potential medicinal properties.
